## MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 327, 358, 345]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Pure Mathematics 1 (P1)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 370, 418, 386]]<|/det|>
Candidates answer on the Question Paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 392, 460, 408]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: List of Formulae (MF9)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 418, 390, 435]]<|/det|>
READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 448, 787, 465]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name in the spaces at the top of this page.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 464, 325, 479]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 479, 504, 495]]<|/det|>
You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 494, 504, 510]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 509, 380, 525]]<|/det|>
DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 540, 285, 555]]<|/det|>
Answer all the questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 555, 910, 586]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 585, 598, 600]]<|/det|>
The use of an electronic calculator is expected, where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 600, 606, 616]]<|/det|>
You are reminded of the need for clear presentation in your answers.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 630, 609, 646]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 645, 757, 661]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 660, 440, 676]]<|/det|>
The total number of marks for this paper is 75.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 74, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
A function f is defined by \(\mathrm{f}:x\mapsto x^{3} - x^{2} - 8x + 5\) for \(x< a\). It is given that f is an increasing function. Find the largest possible value of the constant \(a\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 87, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 75, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 146, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 74, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
A geometric progression has first term \(3a\) and common ratio \(r\). A second geometric progression has first term \(a\) and common ratio \(-2r\). The two progressions have the same sum to infinity. Find the value of \(r\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 103, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 148, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
The first two terms of an arithmetic progression are 15 and 19 respectively. The first two terms of a second arithmetic progression are 420 and 415 respectively. The two progressions have the same sum of the first \(n\) terms. Find the value of \(n\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 103, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 72, 920, 109]]<|/det|>
Machines in a factory make cardboard cones of base radius \(r \text{ cm}\) and vertical height \(h \text{ cm}\). The volume, \(V \text{ cm}^3\), of such a cone is given by \(V = \frac{1}{3} \pi r^2 h\). The machines produce cones for which \(h + r = 18\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 123, 156, 142]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 123, 381, 142]]<|/det|>
Show that \(V = 6\pi r^2 - \frac{1}{3}\pi r^3\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 123, 920, 142]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 395, 186, 414]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 395, 920, 432]]<|/det|>
Given that \(r\) can vary, find the non-zero value of \(r\) for which \(V\) has a stationary value and show that the stationary value is a maximum.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 415, 920, 432]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 72, 667, 92]]<|/det|>
The points \(A\) (1, 1) and \(B\) (5, 9) lie on the curve \(6y = 5x^2 - 18x + 19\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 104, 156, 123]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 103, 744, 123]]<|/det|>
Show that the equation of the perpendicular bisector of \(AB\) is \(2y = 13 - x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 104, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 613, 92]]<|/det|>
The perpendicular bisector of \(AB\) meets the curve at \(C\) and \(D\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 109, 153, 128]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 102, 920, 153]]<|/det|>
Find, by calculation, the distance \(CD\), giving your answer in the form \(\sqrt{\left(\frac{p}{q}\right)}\), where \(p\) and \(q\) are integers.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 134, 920, 153]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 75, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 146, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 74, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
Relative to an origin \(O\), the position vectors of two points \(P\) and \(Q\) are \(\mathbf{p}\) and \(\mathbf{q}\) respectively. The point \(R\) is such that \(PQR\) is a straight line with \(Q\) the mid-point of \(PR\). Find the position vector of \(R\) in terms of \(\mathbf{p}\) and \(\mathbf{q}\), simplifying your answer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 103, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 74, 148, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 920, 109]]<|/det|>
The vector \(6\mathbf{i} + a\mathbf{j} + b\mathbf{k}\) has magnitude 21 and is perpendicular to \(3\mathbf{i} + 2\mathbf{j} + 2\mathbf{k}\). Find the possible values of \(a\) and \(b\), showing all necessary working.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 87, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 74, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 452, 92]]<|/det|>
Functions f and g are defined for \(x > 3\) by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[435, 98, 562, 129]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{f:x\mapsto\frac{1}{x^{2} - 9},}\]

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[435, 133, 559, 152]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{g:x\mapsto 2x - 3.}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 170, 156, 189]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 170, 499, 189]]<|/det|>
Find and simplify an expression for \(\mathrm{gg}(x)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 170, 920, 189]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 505, 186, 523]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 505, 620, 524]]<|/det|>
Find an expression for \(\mathrm{f}^{-1}(x)\) and state the domain of \(\mathrm{f}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 507, 920, 526]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 75, 104, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[371, 84, 660, 222]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 243, 667, 266]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows part of the curve \(y = \frac{1}{2} (x^{4} - 1)\), defined for \(x \geqslant 0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 276, 156, 294]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 276, 695, 295]]<|/det|>
Find, showing all necessary working, the area of the shaded region.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 276, 920, 295]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 584, 186, 602]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 584, 920, 618]]<|/det|>
Find, showing all necessary working, the volume obtained when the shaded region is rotated through \(360^{\circ}\) about the \(x\)-axis.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 602, 920, 619]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]
